abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Project Performance Audit
            Report (PPAR) on the Fourth Railway Project, on the Fifth
            Railway Project, and on the Kosovo Railway Project. For all
            three projects, inception was fast and preparation
            problematic. Differences of opinion between the Bank and the
            Borrower regarding objectives complicated both the
            preparation and implementation phases, and led to
            non-achievement of financial targets.  None of the three
            projects benefitted from the experience of  preceding ones
            partly because haste to proceed with the next lending
            operation did not allow time for reflection, and partly
            because neither the Bank nor the Borrower were convinced
            that study of the past is useful in planning the future.
            Little importance was attached to in-house review and,
            indeed, it was the Bank who advised CYR, and CYR took the
            advice that preparation of Project Completion report (PCRs)
            ought to be done by outside consultants. The fact remains
            that PCR preparation is an educational experience for those
            who prepare them and this experience was lost to CYR and to
            the Railway Transport Enterprise (RTEs). By the same token,
            the leisurely, and somewhat too generous, editing in EMENA
            of the Borrower's draft PCRs, demonstrates the limited
            significance attached to lesson-learned from past mistakes.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Fourth Highway Project Consists of a
            three-year slice (1974-76) of the RTEs' investment
            plans for 1973-77 and the proposed loan would be allocated
            and disbursed against expenditures after June 30, 1974 for
            specific investments for: (i) completion of the 1964
            Modernization Program, including remaining sections of
            electrification, signaling and telecommunications, and
            marshalling yards; (ii) related investments necessary to
            realize the full benefits from the 1964 Modernization
            Program, mainly track rehabilitation, further signaling, and
            modernization of the Sarajevo junction; and (iii) staff
            training, and technical assistance by foreign consultants,
            mainly to assist the CYR and RTEs in preparing
            technical/economic studies and future five-year development plans.
